Description: Forty-nine marbles: mostly spherical, but including a few which are pear-shaped. The marbles are made of various materials, the number of each being: porphyry 15, limestone 21, breccia 4, quartz 9. Five of the quartz marbles have three white veins running through the stone, which has been deliberately cut so that the veins are in the centre of the marble, no doubt as a decorative effect.
Curator's comments: The majority of parallels for uninscribed marbles are Early Dynastic, although marbles of the same type occur in Predynastic graves; see E. R. Ayrton & W. L. S. Loat, 'Pre-dynastic cemetery at El Mahasna' (London, 1911), pl.XVIII, 1'. The British Museum marbles are said to have been found together with the stone bowl, also numbered 30798 (28). This form of vessel is undoubtedly to be dated to the First Dynasty, and most probably to the earlier part of that period. For similar Early Dynastic marbles, see W. M. F. Petrie, 'Gizeh and Rifeh' (Warminster, 1977, pl.IV; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Tombs of the courtiers and Oxyrhynkos' (London, 1925), pl.VII, 6; T. E. Peet in E. Naville (ed.), ‘The cemeteries of Abydos’ II (London, 1913), pl.X, 3; W. B. Emery, 'Great tombs of the First Dynasty; excavations at Sakkara' II' (London, 1954), 56-9 and pl.XXIX, 233F; W. B. Emery, 'Great tombs of the First Dynasty; excavations at Sakkara' III (London, 1958), 84, nos. 37-8; Compare Z. Y. Saad, 'The excavations at Helwan art and civilization in the first and second Egyptian dynasties' (Norman, 1969) pl.XXXVIa; A. Scharff, ‘Die Altertümer der Vor – und Frühzeit Ägyptens’ II (Berlin, 1929-31), nos. 275-6 and pl.33. For inscribed marbles, see P. Kaplony, 'Die Inschriften der Ägyptischen Frühzeit’, supplement, (Wiesbaden, 1964), 28-30 and abb. 1050 C, 1051-2; P. Kaplony, 'Mitteilungen der Deutschen Archäologischen Instituts Abteilung Kairo' 20 (Wiesbaden, 1965), 6-7; P. Kaplony ‘Beschriftete Kleinfunde in der Sammlung Georges Michailidis Ergebnisse einer Bestandsaufnahme im Sommer 1968’ (Istanbul, 1973), nos. 5-20 (the antiquity of some of the inscriptions on these objects is doubtful).
Acquisition name: Purchased from: R J Moss & Co
